Basic ionic liquids supported on hydroxyapatite-encapsulated γ-Fe2O3 nanocrystallites: An efficient magnetic and recyclable heterogeneous catalyst for aqueous Knoevenagel condensation Yan Zhang a b Yingwei Zhao a b Chungu Xia a ⁎ a State Key Laboratory for Oxo Synthesis and Selective Oxidation, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou, Lanzhou 730000, PR China b Graduate School of the Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +86 931 4968056; fax: +86 931 8277088. Graphical abstract A series of basic ionic liquids functionalized hydroxyapatite-encapsulated γ-Fe2O3 magnetic nanoparticles were used as efficient heterogeneous catalysts for aqueous Knoevenagel condensation under mild conditions. Separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture is readily achieved by simple magnetic decantation and the catalyst could be easily recycled without appreciable loss of catalytic activity. A series of basic ionic liquids functionalized hydroxyapatite-encapsulated γ-Fe2O3 magnetic nanoparticles were synthesized and characterized by XRD, XPS, HRTEM, IR and BET. These magnetic nanoparticles were used as efficient heterogeneous catalysts for aqueous Knoevenagel condensation under mild conditions and excellent results for extended substrates were obtained. In comparison with the control experiments, the high activity is ascribed to the cooperativity between the base sites generated by framework hydroxyapatite and supported basic ionic liquids. Separation of the catalyst from the reaction mixture was readily achieved by simple magnetic decantation and the catalyst could be easily recycled without appreciable loss of catalytic activity. Keywords Magnetic separation Basic ionic liquids Knoevenagel condensation Cooperativity 1 Introduction Condensation reactions, known to be catalyzed by base, are of great importance for the synthesis of pharmaceutical and fine chemicals. Industrially, these reactions are indeed carried out in the homogeneous phase with KOH or NaOH [1]. Using these bases, however, have numerous disadvantages such as waste production, corrosion and no catalyst recovery. Thus it is an exciting challenge to find new Brønsted-type basic catalysts with high activity and selectivity [2–5]. On the other hand, ionic liquids (ILs), a novel class of versatile solvent, have emerged and employed as promising homogeneous catalysis media or catalyst itself [6–8] because of their unique physicochemical properties including negligible vapor pressure, wide liquid range, higher ionic conductivity and excellent solubility [9–12]. Among them, basic ionic liquids used in some base-catalyzed processes have aroused unprecedented interest because they have numerous advantages such as high catalytic efficiency and easy catalyst recycling over the combination of inorganic base and ILs [13,14]. Although the ability of ILs has been demonstrated successfully in many reactions, the chemical industry still prefers to use heterogeneous catalyst system because of the easy separation, thus supported ILs is highly desirable. It was demonstrated that supported ILs, instead of homogenous ILs, led to further improvements in efficiency [15,16]. Indeed, we successfully performed the hydrolysis of propylene carbonate reaction using polystyrene resin supported ILs catalysts [17]. Despite of the obtained high selectivity, the tedious recycle of catalysts via filtration and the inevitable loss of solid catalyst in the separation process limited its application. To further address the issue of recyclability and reusability, magnetic nanoparticles were used as catalyst supports for simple magnetic separation [18–20]. Ultrafine magnetic nanoparticles, however, always tend to undergo agglomeration due to the large surface area-to-volume ratio and the magnetic dipole–dipole attractions between particles. It was reported that formation of a passive coating of inert materials such as polymers, carbons, and silicas on the surfaces of iron oxide nanoparticles could help prevent their aggregation in liquid and improve their chemical stability [21–23]. Hydroxyapatite (HAP), i.e. Ca10(PO4)6(OH)2, as an important biocompatible inorganic nanomaterial, is potentially useful for creating a high-performance heterogeneous catalyst [24]. Owing to its good stability, high surface area and easy synthesis, hydroxyapatite-encapsulated magnetic γ-Fe2O3 nanocrystallites have recently been used as heterogeneous catalytic supports [25,26]. Herein, we report a catalytic system based on hydroxyapatite-encapsulated magnetic γ-Fe2O3 nanocrystallites functionalized with basic ILs, which proved to be highly efficient for low temperature Knoevenagel liquid phase reaction. The procedure is environmentally friendly and efficient by using water as media for reactions instead of traditional hazard organic solvents and catalyst can be easily separated with an external magnet, without using extra organic solvents and additional filtration steps. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials FeCl2·4H2O, FeCl3·6H2O, NH4OH solution (25%), Ca(NO3)2·4H2O, (NH4)2HPO4, Co(NO3)2·6H2O, NaPF6 and malononitrile were of analytical grade and were used as received. Benzaldehyde and 2-furaldehyde were distilled before used. 3-Chloropropyltriethoxysilane and imidazole were purchased from Aldrich. Chloromethylated polystyrene (4–5% Cl content and 2% cross-linked with divinylbenzene). 2.2 Physical measurements 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a MERCURY-PLUS 400MHz spectrometer. FT-IR spectra were registered with a Bruker IFS HRFT-IR Spectrometer infrared spectrophotometer. Nitrogen content was determined by combustion analysis in a Vario EL elemental analyzer. XRD was carried out on a PANalytical X’pert Pro Diffractometer. XPS was performed on a VG ESCALAB 210 spectrometer, all binding energies were calibrated using the C2p peak at 285.0eV as a reference. High-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) micrographs were obtained with a JEM-2010 electron microscope. The BET surface area measurements were performed on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 instrument at liquid nitrogen temperature. ESI-MS analysis was performed by using a Waters micromass ZQ alliance spectrometer. 2.3 Synthesis of catalyst HAP-encapsulated γ-Fe2O3 (HAP-γ-Fe2O3) [25], [Bmim]OH [27], 1-methyl-3-(3-propyltriethoxysilane)imidazolium chloride (1) [28], 1-butyl-3-(3-propyltriethoxysilane)imidazolium chloride (2), 1-octyl-3-(3-propyltriethoxysilane)imidazolium chloride (3), and 1-hexadecyl-3-(3-propyltriethoxysilane)imidazolium chloride (4) were synthesized according to the references. Grafting of 1-methyl-3-(3-propyltriethoxysilane)imidazolium hydroxyl on HAP-γ-Fe2O3 (5), 1-butyl-3-(3-propyltriethoxysilane)imidazolium hydroxyl on HAP-γ-Fe2O3 (6), 1-octyl-3-(3-propyltriethoxysilane)imidazolium hydroxyl on HAP-γ-Fe2O3 (7), 1-hexadecyl-3-(3-propyltriethoxysilane)imidazolium hydroxyl on HAP-γ-Fe2O3 (8) and 1-methyl imidazolium hydroxyl modified polystyrene resin (9) [17] were shown in Supporting Information. 2.4 General procedure for Knoevenagel condensation To a solution of benzaldehyde (2mmol, 0.21g) and malononitrile (2mmol, 0.13g) in water (10mL) in a round-bottom flask, the supported basic ionic liquid magnetic catalyst (0.025g) was added. The reaction mixture was stirred at 30°C for 1h (stirring rate>1000r/min, lower than 1000r/min resulting relatively low yield). After extraction by ethyl ether (3× 15mL), the solvent was evaporated and the resulted solid were dissolved in 10mL ethyl acetate. Decane was then added as an internal standard for GC analysis. Qualitative analysis was conducted with an Agilent 6890 GC–MS and quantitative analysis were conducted with an Agilent 6820 GC equipped with a FID. For the model reaction of benzaldehyde with malononitrile or ethyl cyanoacetate, isolated yield was obtained by using column chromatography, together with GC yield. While for the experiment of extended substrates, only GC yield was obtained for comparison. 2.5 General procedure for recycle experiment The reaction of benzaldehyde with malononitrile in water as a model reaction was again studied. When the reaction was completed, a column magnet was externally applied with the aim of placing the supported basic ionic liquid magnetic catalyst on the side wall of the reactor and the reaction solution was removed. The catalyst was washed repeated with ethyl ether and dried under vacuum at 60°C for 8h to eliminate any water trapped from moisture and reused for subsequent reactions. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization As shown in Scheme 1 , five supported basic ionic liquids (SBILs), i.e. 5–9, were synthesized via silane chemistry, so as to investigate the effect of supports and structure of the cation on the activity. The SBILs can be classified into two types: one with HAP-γ-Fe2O3 as magnetic basic support and functionalized with basic ILs with variable length of alkyl chain (5–8) on the cation moiety, and the other with non-basic polystyrene resin as support (9). All SBILs were characterized and confirmed by XRD, XPS, HRTEM, IR and BET. Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of SBILs 5, together with those of HAP and HAP-γ-Fe2O3. In comparison with HAP, HAP-γ-Fe2O3 showed extra peaks at 30.2°, 35.7° and 43.6°, corresponding to the (220), (311), and (400) reflections of γ-Fe2O3 [29,30], respectively. The formation and existence of γ-Fe2O3 in the HAP-γ-Fe2O3 was also evident from the results conducted by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS): the positions of the Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 peaks in the HAP-γ-Fe2O3 were 710.5 and 724.3eV, which is in good agreement with the peaks of γ-Fe2O3. After HAP-γ-Fe2O3 grafted with ILs, the resulted SBILs 5 still retained the reflections of HAP and γ-Fe2O3, whereas the intensity of diffraction peaks for the HAP-γ-Fe2O3 was relatively lower than those of the parent material, presumably due to the smaller size of the particles. Fig. 2 shows high-resolution transmission electron microscopy image. It can be clearly seen from image (Fig. 2A) that γ-Fe2O3 was coated with a layer HAP. The γ-Fe2O3 nanocrystallites distributed uniformly within the host HAP matrix and have a mean diameter (d) of ca. 1–3nm, which was much smaller than the reported results (8nm) [25]. The black region in micrograph (Fig. 2B) could result either from agglomerated nanoparticles or from modified nanoparticles. From the combined observation of the IR and elementary analysis characterizations (see Table 1 ), we could conclude that it could be resulted from modification with ILs rather than agglomeration. In order to warrant the successful functionalization HAP-γ-Fe2O3 with basic ILs, IR is employed to give detailed investigation of the obtained SBILs (Fig. 3 ). In comparison with the naked HAP-γ-Fe2O3, a significant features observed for the SBILs 5 were the appearance of the characteristic peaks of imidazolium moiety at 3170 and 3121cm−1 (C–H stretching vibration of imidazole ring), 2980 and 2936cm−1 (–CH3 and –CH2 stretching vibration, respectively), 1574cm−1 (C–C and C–N stretching vibration of imidazole ring) [31], indicating the definite graft of basic ILs. Note that the contribution of the hydroxyl band (near 3390cm−1) and Si–O band (near 1017cm−1) was absent in all SBILs, due to overlapping by the framework of HAP. IR spectra of SBILs with variable length of alkyl chain, i.e. 6–8 (6 is shown in Fig. 2 as a typical) are close to that of 5. For SBILs 9, the presence of ILs was also evident from the characteristic peaks of imidazolium at 1570cm−1 and hydroxyl at the 3392cm−1. From the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the unmodified HAP-γ-Fe2O3, SBILs 5 and 6 (shown in Fig. 4 ), one can see that all modified samples exhibited an isotherm shape similar to that of HAP-γ-Fe2O3, suggesting no obvious change of structure after modification. Meanwhile, it was found that the HAP-γ-Fe2O3 and 5 exhibits broad pore distribution (2–100nm). HRTEM image indicated that the pore size (20–100nm) is not the pore of the material itself, and its formation could be due to the capillary condensation in the secondary mesopores. The surface area and pore volume obtained from N2 sorption isotherms and the loading of organic compounds obtained from elementary analysis in all SBILs are compiled in Table 1. After surface modification, a decrease of surface area (around 8–20m2/g), pore volume and pore size is observed as compared to the parent HAP-γ-Fe2O3, could be likely due to the presence of functional groups likely block the pore of the HAP and decrease the interparticle spaces. As for SBILs themselves, BET, pore volume and pore size were found to increase with the length of alkyl chain, due to the opposite trend of the loading. 3.2 Knoevenagel condensation reactions The catalytic performances of all SBILs were evaluated under identical reaction conditions (Scheme 2 ). The results were listed in Table 2 . As it has been found, the selectivity to the Knoevenagel product is >99% so conversions are also the yields of product. Considering that the condensation is a weak base-catalyzed reaction, the bad result of a blank test in the absence of catalyst was not unexpected (entry 1). Correspondingly, the carrier showed a conversion of 64% in this system could be due to the weak basicity of hydroxyapatite (entry 2). With only addition of homogenous basic ILs ([Bmim]OH), the control experiment showed a moderate conversion (59%) higher than the blank test (entry 3). However, it was found that the basic ILs modified HAP-γ-Fe2O3 (5–8) showed much higher activity than either HAP-γ-Fe2O3 or [Bmim]OH (entries 2–7). A reasonable explanation was that there could be cooperative activation between base carrier and basic ILs. In order to validate the hypothesis, SBILs 9 (entry 8) with non-basic polystyrene resin as carrier and modified with the same basic ILs as that of 5 was synthesized and used as catalyst in the control experiments. The obtained conversion (66%) was remarkably lower than magnetic catalyst 5, almost as low as that of the homogenous basic ILs, meant that the base site of supports is indispensable during the cooperative activation. This was supported further by the catalytic results of the physical mixture of the homogeneous catalyst ([Bmim]OH) and the basic carrier HAP-γ-Fe2O3 (entry 9), which showed activity, though slightly fall, comparable to that of the corresponding magnetic SBILs 5. On the basis of the above mentioned, the cooperativity could be existed between the basic magnetic nanoparticles carrier and the supported basic ILs, which greatly enhanced the activity. Interestingly, as to the SBILs with variable length of alkyl chain on the imidazolium moiety, we found that the activity decreased though slightly, but gradually in the sequence of CH3 >C4H9 >C8H17 >C16H33 (entries 4–7), which could be ascribed to the low accessibility to the basic centers with increase of steric hindrance as well as the less loading basic centers. The solvents effect on the activity was also investigated and the result was shown in Table 2 (entries 4, 10, and 11). A significant drop in reaction activity was observed for the hydrophobic solvent, whereas a higher reaction activity was observed for H2O under identical conditions. It was proposed that hydrophilic supports could preactivate the reagents by interaction of the carbonyl with the acidic hydroxyl of solvent, affording reaction rate enhancement [32,33]. When malononitrile was replaced by ethyl cyanoacetate (entries 12 and 13), higher reaction temperature and longer reaction time were needed to afford high conversions. The catalysis substrates were then extended to several aromatic, aliphatic and heteroaromatic aldehydes with malononitrile using magnetic SBILs 5 and the results were summarized in Table 3 . All the reactions were able to undergo the corresponding Knoevenagel condensation well. Excellent conversion was obtained when using cyclohexanone and aldehyde derivatives of furan as reaction substrates (entries 1 and 2). In addition, it was found that substitute groups of aromatic aldehydes have an effect on Knoevenagel reaction, aldehyde with withdrawing group was observed to be more reactive than that of electron donating group (entries 3 and 4). Moreover, in the case of hydroxybenzaldehydes, the 2-substituted isomer (entry 5) was less reactive than the 4-substitued isomer, probably due to the increased steric hindrance. For the aliphatic aldehyde, the short chain aldehyde was found to be more reactive than the long chain aldehyde (entries 6 and 7). Phenylpropyl aldehyde and cinnamaldehyde were found to be much less reactive than other aldehydes in the Knoevenagel condensation with only approximately 60% conversion being observed (entries 8 and 9). Considering that one key feature of our catalysts was magnetic response, we investigated the reusability and the recycling use of the SBILs catalyst, and found that the catalyst could be completely recovered with an external permanent magnet, giving GC yield still higher than 97% after four recycling during Knoevenagel condensation (shown in Fig. 5 ). 4 Conclusions In summary, hydroxyapatite-encapsulated γ-Fe2O3 nanoparticles were readily synthesized and functionalized with basic ILs via silane chemistry to create surface basic sites. The basic magnetic nanoparticles were used as efficient heterogeneous catalysts for the aqueous Knoevenagel condensation reaction of various aldehydes with malononitrile under mild conditions. Cooperativity between the basic magnetic nanoparticle carrier and SBILs could be responding to the significant raise on catalytic activity. Increasing the length of substitute alkyl chain of ionic liquids on SBILs resulted in the opposite trend in activity. The magnetic catalyst could be facilely isolated from the reaction mixture by simple magnetic decantation using a permanent magnet and could be reused at least four times without significant degradation in activity.
